data.text: Panniers vs Trailers for Long-Distance Touring?
Trailers vs painers Thoughts?
With panniers I can hop on a bus and get whisked to the other end of the city for a few dollars. Trailer does not offer that option.
data.author: Thomas Wilson

data.text: Yup. Easier to organize your gear as well
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Panniers all day
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: Painners. Although it might depend on where you are going. If its from home to home trailer most likely? If Panniers make sure your rack/s are well supported and balance out the weight and double bag your gear.
data.author: Evan Chapple

data.text: Panniers all the way. My panniers weigh 1lb for the set. Find me a trailer that weighs remotely close to that and I’ll consider it 🥺
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: Well, seems like apples to oranges, as they say. Panniers have their place as do trailers. The panniers create a heavy bike, where as a loaded trailer, the bike floats. So comparing weights as you have are not really comparable. Now to be clear I'm talking about a 1 wheel trailer.
data.author: Pat Matson

data.text: It’s very comparable. Trailers weigh a bike down a lot more than fully loaded panniers do. Have fun struggling up that 9% grade mountain pass at 3mph with your trailer while I’m cruising at 10mph with my panniers.
data.author: Ty Dawley

data.text: ?, Silly. It all depends on the motor. At 71 my motor is fine with either. I totally disagree with the statment that trailers weigh the bike down. Trailers let the bike float. Biggest problem with trailers is they are unwieldy and in maneuvering in tight places. But hey, there is always a trade off, choose which is best for one, just be accurate.
data.author: Pat Matson

data.text: Sorry Pat but NOTHING being hauled behind your bike allows the bike to float. Especially when you load the trailer. And most who use a trailer overload. I think the problem is tunnel vision from both sides of the fence. Those that use panniers think it's the only way. Those who use a trailer expound endlessly on it's usefulness. I used a BOB on a few trips when my wife/daughter went with me. My normal pannier weight for a 7-10 day trip/camping and resupplying food as intervals is 20 lbs or less. 10 per pannier or less. My tent weight /3 person Nemo is an additional 4lbs. I really didn't like hauling the BOB and it was a pain when stopping or go ariund/through obstacles. For you the trailer is a perfect fit but don't try and say your pulling a cloud. More like a stormy cloud full of rain.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: And my "motor" heart & lungs work great at 67 years old. Pulse at rest is 52/64 BP is 110/70.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: Agree to disagree. The bike is much easier to move, especially off road. When the similar weight is distributed in panniers, the bike is coming in at easy 50 lbs, it does not move freely it sink in the dirt & sand & is a true anchor on the road, being clumsy to move. No comparison. I use both depending on the situation. With a trailer, off road, I use front panniers. Pretty sure I never said cloud, but hey I'll use that term now. PS IF one is using 4 panniers I can see 10 lbs each, but man you pack light IF all you haul is 20 lbs plus your tent, plus food, plus water. plus your bike, hmmm, sound like 50 +/- lbs to me. But hey have fun. I do & will as I float my cloud down the way!
data.author: Pat Matson

data.text: Your words were et the bike float". As in lite weight "like" a cloud in my mind. Never said you said cloud. I only use 2 panniers and my weight for a week/10 days is 10 lbs or less per pannier. As I said...everyone has tunnel vision concerning their gear. Most pannier people use orlieb. I wouldn't use them if they were free. I hate the mounting system. I use Arkel Orcas. And have used them for almost 15 years with no failures.
data.author: Rick Hancock

data.text: Panniers
data.author: John Youker

data.text: Whatever works best for you
data.author: Stan Horwitz

data.text: Trailers are handy but the jostle you around a lot. Panniers are smaller and you’re not able to fit as much stuff but you’re more in control and faster.
data.author: T.J. Bunkall

data.text: Trailers are good for grocery shopping and shorter distances
data.author: T.J. Bunkall

data.text: Trailers for long mountain biking tours while on a tight budget in remote areas. Carry enough groceries in the trailer for a long trek, but unhitch and stash it for shorter bikepacking trips and day trips.
data.author: Scott England

data.text: Is it pronounced "pan-EERZ" or pan-ee-EIZ"?
data.author: Shaunanigan Wu

data.text: pan-yers
data.author: Julia Poelstra

data.text:
https://youtu.be/PmXnaX-5d8g
The CORRECT way to pronounce "PANNIER" (NOT what you think!)
youtube.com
data.author: Julia Poelstra

data.text: Panniers Though I’d last the kids to a board before sticking them in the pannier
data.author: Merwyn Ambrose

data.text: Same question I'm wondering about. For me typically, my B.O.B.(Beast Of Burden) I've used only on offroad long distance tours. Trailer lets one take more than panniers do & larger objects than one can fit into panniers. Trailers leave the bike riding lighter espically in heavy off road conditions. IF one is to use a trailer heavy load up front. With trailers you are very long, parking is a special skill for the older trailers, newer ones, like Burley are quite great, though to a tune of 500$! Panniers keep everything close, & dense. Easier to park. Sorting is similar in both. It really depends on your route. I'm going to do some test runs with both, with the same gear. My hope is to head from N. Central Oregon to San Diego in the fall.
data.author: Pat Matson

data.text: Panniers. My single wheel trailer was wagging the bike. I got rid of it.
data.author: Whan-Soo James Kang

data.text: Panniers
data.author: Jeff Pitts

data.text: Panniers for sure
data.author: Julie Rossall

data.text: I like both and I have both. Trailers are heavier but easier to carry more. Panniers carry less but weigh less. Trailers can be cheaper when you factor the cost of panniers/bags, and racks all in. Panniers tend to be more solid on the bike if supported by a good rack though while trailers will push and pull. If a not real sturdy rack the bags will sway side to side which I'd prefer a trailer over that.
data.author: Natalie Stenger

data.text: I have both and I’ve toured with both. In fact I even have both a single AND a double wheel trailer I thought the BOB would be great especially in trying to maneuver those confounded rumble strips!!! Turns out, the BOB was fishy so much so that my quick release skewer bent!! The SAME load with my two wheel was like a cloud floating along behind me Frankly I WISH I could pack everything into panniers but, when I do that then I pay a price when mounting/dismounting. Believe me when I say it a BIG enough issue with me and my weak right leg that I’m seriously considering a step-thru. So there’s my two cents worth Thanks for reading If you respond, please be civil and respectful
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: Yeah, BOBs looked neat in the 90s but after you spend 3 or 4 days on the road and realize you could extend that to 5 & 6 easily 'cause you're tending to buy and discard what you consume, the trailer becomes a squirly scooter just waiting to make demands on you. Much of the only real damage I've done to a bike is the result of hauling that which it wasn't designed to.
data.author: Chris Davis

data.text: I'm curious; you meant a two wheel trailer is easier to maneuver and feels easy to haul than one wheel?.. I'm stuck between choosing one wheel and two wheeler, based on what is easy to haul
data.author: Kyagera Ivan

data.text: in MY case, yes
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: an someone who grew up on bikes but then my last bike at 12-14yo was a step-through…. Going to a non-step as an adult was hard.😅 (esp as I didn’t ride that much) The first embarrassment was when I was about 24yo and just forgot it wasn’t step-trough and it toppled my bike at a busy intersection. Everyone saw 😳 Even now (44yo) I have to consciously remember to high-swing my leg over. But tbf I haven’t ridden as much as when I was pre-14yo.
data.author: Debra Baum

data.text: at 23 I suffered a trampoline accident that left me paralyzed for three weeks Took a Year to Learn to walk again I’m 66 now. The price I’ve paid from that accident is a weakened right leg The absolute hardest thing for me is to mount and dismount a standard diamond frame bike I could be wrong but I think a step-thru would be a solution
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: that’s really tough 💕 A step through still requires you to lift you leg but you don’t have to do that up+rotation. My bike before I was 13 was a step-through and I loved it - I never felt that love for my subsequent “racer”. (Part of the reason I fell over is I had beef used to step-throughs) How have you been managing up til now? (That doesn’t mean you have to continue 💕). Can you try someone’s step-through to test the theory. In my community we have some great Bicycle User Groups. Or even our local Buy Nothing Group would sort out locals. That hip-up action to get over the seat (and panniers) is hard. But you have to have the seat set at riding height so you’ll alway have to do some of that action. Definitely check it out ☺️
data.author: Debra Baum

data.text: I haven't made up my mind on this one just yet...
data.author: Andrew Guinn Patten

data.text: One consideration: Portage Pack - a dry bag with shoulder straps , put everything in it, and it in a trailer.. then you can wear the trailer & lift your bicycle in your hands to climb stairs, fence stiles road washouts & etc.
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: Maybe you can do that but I doubt I could, speaking as a 5’0” female.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: Bike packing bags require the Discipline to leave things home. being light, bring less. use hotels.. (safer - as a woman, too..)
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: I think best you go with trailers.
data.author: David Bouk

data.text: Can unhitched a trailer but you can load it to much too I like but it is a drag
data.author: John Findlay

data.text: I have no bike-trailer experience, but I notice when people mention conversion from trailer to pannier to shed the trailer weight. I made a similar conversion from recumbent trike to recumbent bike, shedding the weight of that 3rd wheel. My experience with panniers & frame packs is that there are a lot of opportunities for centering & balancing & special packaging. Simply moving rack & panniers forward & down from above the rear wheel to low under the recumbent seat made a huge difference.
data.author: Mike Dannheim

data.text: , I found the same on a recumbent. LWB, panniers and weight on the back - fine. SWB recumbent with kids school bag on rack at back - thought I was going to die as steering was so light turning response at speed didn’t exist. CLWB with light luggage on the back, front wheel kept coming off the ground on steep climbs every time I pushed the pedals. Found some panniers weight on the front wheel (CLWB) or under the frame / seat (CLWB / SWB) as you did worked.
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: Bottom line: frame builders of many years experience and in-depth detailed technical knowledge of bicycles have been building and perfecting the design of touring bikes to carry racks and panniers for many many decades. I know of no frame specifically built to pull a trailer. Reflect on that and ask yourself why?
data.author: Trevor Piper

data.text:
Two examples: https://surlybikes.com/bikes/haulin
Cargo Bike Frames | Specialized Cargo Haulin'
surlybikes.com
data.author: Steve Williams

data.text: Are you being funny or thick? A cargo bicycle frame is not built to pull a trailer. The frame is built to carry cargo.
data.author: Trevor Piper

data.text: I get up to 50 miles a day propulsion from the sun And carry up to 150lbs of camping stuff with this rig….
data.author: David O'Neill
David O'Neill

data.text: Been everywhere with my BOB since I got it in 2011..Love it!
data.author: Nick Mallett

data.text: I'm thinking of similar trailer type, still wondering if 1 wheel is better and easier to pull than 2 wheel. Great bike set-up here💕
data.author: Kyagera Ivan

data.text: I'm a pannier fan for grocery shopping and touring, primarily because it doesn't change the dimensions of my bike (eg: trailers are harder to take on a train and through gates. I feel self-concious when crossing at traffic lights because of the extra length. The trailer does pull back on bumps but you get used to it. My bike with panniers on it is roughly the same width as my bike with me on it. I've used my cargo trailer to move house and it was the right tool for the job (it can carry more weight and bulkier items like a vacuum cleaner). I also loaned it to a scout troop, who went touring as a group and didn't have enough bags. They took turns towing the trailer with communal gear.
data.author: Richard Neville

data.text:
To throw another option in, what are peoples’ thoughts on an Extra wheel (as opposed to BOB) style. Can combine with rear rack on bike if additional carrying capacity is needed. https://extrawheel.com/categories/bicycle-trailers/
Bike trailers Extrawheel - for an expedition and behind the city
extrawheel.com
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: I have looked at them for desert travel, for the extra water cargo. I think they’re an elegant solution.
data.author: Sam Reich

data.text: I like that their another alternative
data.author: Debra Baum

data.text: I have thought about them but have not used or experienced them.
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: Panniers won't go flat and very unlikely to have a mechanical tha end
data.author: Mark Holland

data.text: Both lol
data.author: George Homer

data.text: my yellow lab wont fit in my panniers
data.author: Ray Brantner

data.text: but have you really tried? 😅
data.author: Debra Baum

data.text: I didn’t know how to spell panniers either so I looked it up!
data.author: Michael Finger

data.text: I can carry less than 15kg of luggage (for a week) in 2 panniers with the tiny tent on the top of the rack. I choose to spread that weight into 4 panniers. I can load water and food onto that… What I don’t get is what are people carrying that needs so much more capacity, do you really need a trailer? Are the bikes not capable of carrying? My previous light aluminium touring machine couldn’t handle much more, thus I kept it light, and have light equipment from backpacking.
data.author: David Sykes

data.text: I have thus: I can add a bag behind the saddle ...
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: After using a single wheel trailer on a decent I'm not a fan they can tend to push you when braking, I prefer panniers but then it's getting used to the weight and balance.
data.author: Steven Spencer

data.text: I have had both but love my burley!
data.author: Ben Ward

data.text: Weight
data.author: Patrick J McDonald

data.text: Bikepacking bags
data.author: Bridget McGill

data.text: Credit Card….
data.author: Ivan Martin

data.text: Similar to deciding between Car Roof-Boot v Trailer?
data.author: Michael Woolaghan

data.text: I’m a outlier. 80 years old and still touring albeit more slowly - always with camp gear and usually internationally. Caveat - coming from years of mountaineering and backpacking my camp gear is ultra light. If my gear and supplies won’t fit comfortably in my panniers I know I am carrying too much. I don’t add a trailer - I minimize the load. Step through or over is not a concern as my load is carried low front and rear and about half of recent international trips have been on my Bike Friday, Diamond frame Llama model. I always step over not through in any case. Trailers are difficult to fly and hard to get into that occasional motel room and nearly impossible in elevators.
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: yes sir that is solid advice. I am a minimalist.
data.author: Joseph Koziol

data.text: I read trailers cause more punctures, and can lead to all sorts of rear end problems. I recently did a hostel overnight with just a bike packing saddle pack and a front bag. I'd go panniers, and super lightweight kit.
data.author: Eddie Energie

data.text: Depending on my trip I use both. I have an Extrawheel trailer. It has a 700x40c tyre and it carries panniers.
data.author: Ian Stapo

data.text: We got a 2nd hand bob trailer as we were breaking spokes on an older tandem we had. We take that for the camping gear for the 2 of us and then our small normal panniers are used for the likes of sandiches, waterproofs etc.
data.author: Skogar Iceland

data.text: If we were touring on individual bikes and were buying new we might well have gone for panniers instead. Trailer has been good although limits speed downhill a bit. Tracks very well and I've been very pleased with it. To me it depends on - how much you want to carry. My suggestion would be is there any possibility of you borrowing anyone's kit for a test run and seeing what the advantages and disadvantages are of both.
data.author: Skogar Iceland

data.text: Trailer is more akward in some situations (we struggle with a tndem on public transport so it doesn't really make much difference) and less so in others, as we are narrower with the bob. My only other word of warning is the more capacity you have, the more you are tempted to put in and the heavier the load will be. :-)
data.author: Skogar Iceland

data.text: I would use panniers if I want to be more nimble and trailers if I want to carry a huge load.
data.author: Kowshik Noor

data.text: I myself preffer grocery stores .
data.author: Michael C Bradford

data.text: Another wheel to be broker and make problems on the way is not good option.
data.author: Andrzej Budnik

data.text: I love my trailer/ Water Tender. I
data.author: Matthew Coulter

data.text: "no painers, no gainers."
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text:
I would prefer using bikepacking bags, but my very small bike frame doesn't carry much. Next I'd prefer a trailer to keep my bike as light and clean as possible when I'm not touring (I ride a custom frame designed to fit me and can't afford to have two of them). I have an old BOB knock off but haven't used it much. I think the Burley Coho XC trailer looks like a good option. But I imagine I'll use my panniers most often, especially if I don't tour enough to justify buying the Burley Coho XC. But as a nature/landscape photographer I have extra gear to carry. https://www.burley.com/product/coho-xc/?gclid=CjwKCAjwwdWVBhA4EiwAjcYJEPhxjVvs6UDU-kC5vMiAkeOiCrIy7IE1XGUqbOyEwq64w2CiI8lqRRoC158QAvD_BwE
Coho XC Single Wheel Cargo Trailer - Burley Design
burley.com
data.author: Kevin Klasman

data.text: I bought both. Panniers for the road bike and Bob trailer for the Mt bike. I am in the planning stages of a 2200 mile trip
data.author: Nelson Stegall
